column4: Here's a pretty simple question:  If one is sitting at the terminal in a directory with an executable, how does one execute it?
I see - what does the ,/ do?  In other words, why can't I just type it like I might in DOS?
./ tells it to run the thing in the current directory
If you add ./ to your path (which is basically what windows does) -- you don't have to type it
